content.raw: any updates on this?
content.html: any updates on this?

content.raw: @Tom_Xiong Could you describe the procedure you used to come up with those offsets?
content.html: @Tom_Xiong Could you describe the procedure you used to come up with those offsets?

content.raw: I pull the location of the wrist frame from the buffer and input that into the command for controlling the hand trajectory by means of a feedback loop. In theory if the wrist frame was the same frame as the one used to control the trajectory of the hand, the command sent to the hand should just send the frame of the wrist to its current location. This isn't the case. Since the actual hand frame is not in the same location as the wrist frame, sending the buffer wrist frame location to control the hand causes it to not stay in its location rather move the right hand to the right and backwards just a little. Performing this action over time shows the hand slowly moving to the right and backwards. For example location of mysterious hand frame relative to world is 0, 0, 0 and the location of the wrist frame relative to world is -0.1, -0.1, 0. If you send the command for the hand to move to the location of wrist, it will command the hand to move from frame location 0, 0, 0 to -0.1, -0.1, 0. Through this method I was able to deduce that there is an offset to the hand frame. By including the offsets, the hand now moves to locations accordingly without the affect and my feedback loops keeps the wrist maintained in place or moving to desired locations. Essentially I just kept changing offsets until the hand stayed in place while the feedback loop was running.
content.html: I pull the location of the wrist frame from the buffer and input that into the command for controlling the hand trajectory by means of a feedback loop. In theory if the wrist frame was the same frame as the one used to control the trajectory of the hand, the command sent to the hand should just send the frame of the wrist to its current location. This isn't the case. Since the actual hand frame is not in the same location as the wrist frame, sending the buffer wrist frame location to control the hand causes it to not stay in its location rather move the right hand to the right and backwards just a little. Performing this action over time shows the hand slowly moving to the right and backwards. For example location of mysterious hand frame relative to world is 0, 0, 0 and the location of the wrist frame relative to world is -0.1, -0.1, 0. If you send the command for the hand to move to the location of wrist, it will command the hand to move from frame location 0, 0, 0 to -0.1, -0.1, 0. Through this method I was able to deduce that there is an offset to the hand frame. By including the offsets, the hand now moves to locations accordingly without the affect and my feedback loops keeps the wrist maintained in place or moving to desired locations. Essentially I just kept changing offsets until the hand stayed in place while the feedback loop was running.

content.raw: @scpeters has this issue been resolved?
content.html: @scpeters has this issue been resolved?

content.raw: I've had trouble with the `hand_trajectory` topic also, but the `arm_trajectory` topic can be used instead with a motion planner.
content.html: I've had trouble with the hand_trajectory topic also, but the arm_trajectory topic can be used instead with a motion planner.

content.raw: I'm having issues with hand trajectory, which started recently (in the last 3 - 4 days). Hand destination pose always seems to be a little off compared to my request transform. Does anybody else experience this issue?
content.html: I'm having issues with hand trajectory, which started recently (in the last 3 - 4 days). Hand destination pose always seems to be a little off compared to my request transform. Does anybody else experience this issue?

content.raw: We have released an updated package, and the hand frame should now be visible. Please `sudo apt-get update; sudo apt-get dist-upgrade` to try it
content.html: We have released an updated package, and the hand frame should now be visible. Please sudo apt-get update; sudo apt-get dist-upgrade to try it

content.raw: Got the update and grasping works well, but it seems to have broken the fix for the neck.  If you pitch the neck by more than about 25 degrees (0.44 radians), it falls all the way to the chest and does not respond after that.
content.html: Got the update and grasping works well, but it seems to have broken the fix for the neck. If you pitch the neck by more than about 25 degrees (0.44 radians), it falls all the way to the chest and does not respond after that.

content.raw: @dan77062 I'm taking a look at the neck. I thought I had fixed the neck, but maybe not...
content.html: @dan77062 I'm taking a look at the neck. I thought I had fixed the neck, but maybe not...

content.raw:
The issue with the neck is the `controller_gains` in the `lowerNeckPitch` joint. Here's what I see in the urdf from the newest val-description deb:

~~~
  <joint name="lowerNeckPitch" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy="0.0 0.0 0.0" xyz="0.0203518 0.0 0.33845"/>
    <axis xyz="0 1 0"/>
    <parent link="torso"/>
    <child link="lowerNeckPitchLink"/>
    <limit effort="26" lower="0" upper="1.162" velocity="5"/>
    <controller_gains Kd="0" Ki="0" Kp="150"/>
    <dynamics damping="10" friction="0.0"/>
  </joint>
~~~

With Kp=150 and damping=10, I thought it was fixed. I'm double-checking...
content.html:
The issue with the neck is the controller_gains in the lowerNeckPitch joint. Here's what I see in the urdf from the newest val-description deb:

  <joint name="lowerNeckPitch" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy="0.0 0.0 0.0" xyz="0.0203518 0.0 0.33845"/>
    <axis xyz="0 1 0"/>
    <parent link="torso"/>
    <child link="lowerNeckPitchLink"/>
    <limit effort="26" lower="0" upper="1.162" velocity="5"/>
    <controller_gains Kd="0" Ki="0" Kp="150"/>
    <dynamics damping="10" friction="0.0"/>
  </joint>

With Kp=150 and damping=10, I thought it was fixed. I'm double-checking...

content.raw:
issue #96 says it should be:


```
#!c++

  <joint name="lowerNeckPitch" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy="0.0 0.0 0.0" xyz="0.0203518 0.0 0.33845"/>
    <axis xyz="0 1 0"/>
    <parent link="torso"/>
    <child link="lowerNeckPitchLink"/>
    <limit effort="26" lower="0" upper="1.162" velocity="5"/>
    <controller_gains Kd="3" Ki="3" Kp="50"/>
    <dynamics damping="0.1" friction="0.0"/>
```
content.html:
issue #96 says it should be:

  <joint name="lowerNeckPitch" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy="0.0 0.0 0.0" xyz="0.0203518 0.0 0.33845"/>
    <axis xyz="0 1 0"/>
    <parent link="torso"/>
    <child link="lowerNeckPitchLink"/>
    <limit effort="26" lower="0" upper="1.162" velocity="5"/>
    <controller_gains Kd="3" Ki="3" Kp="50"/>
    <dynamics damping="0.1" friction="0.0"/>

content.raw:
Just tried it with the numbers you cited and it works fine.  I was using the numbers above and I guess those were from early comments in issue #96.  

My bad, I should have read through the whole issue!

content.raw:
Hello,

I'm positive I have the latest updates as of yesterday, I can't see any additional hand frames (I do see the finger frames). It's still not clear to me which frame acts as the goal for hand trajectory message (IHMC). It would be great if you could clarify this.
content.html:
Hello,

I'm positive I have the latest updates as of yesterday, I can't see any additional hand frames (I do see the finger frames). It's still not clear to me which frame acts as the goal for hand trajectory message (IHMC). It would be great if you could clarify this.

content.raw:
Just want to agree with Bener; I believe I have the latest of everything, and I do not see any new frames.

I've checked the srcsim tree and val_description trees; nothing there seems appropriate.  The ihmc-open-robotics-software is a bit harder to parse; I may have overlooked the change there.  Did I miss any others?
content.html:
Just want to agree with Bener; I believe I have the latest of everything, and I do not see any new frames.

I've checked the srcsim tree and val_description trees; nothing there seems appropriate. The ihmc-open-robotics-software is a bit harder to parse; I may have overlooked the change there. Did I miss any others?

content.raw: Saw somebody asking about this on another issue so thought I should bump it up. I still don't see the new hand frames. Any idea where I might find them?
content.html: Saw somebody asking about this on another issue so thought I should bump it up. I still don't see the new hand frames. Any idea where I might find them?

content.raw: Yes, same issue as the other one, sorry.
content.html: Yes, same issue as the other one, sorry.

content.raw: @nkoenig 's answer on the telecon was unclear to me, so I want to follow up. Are the hand frames going to be made available or not?
content.html: @nkoenig 's answer on the telecon was unclear to me, so I want to follow up. Are the hand frames going to be made available or not?

content.raw:
Yeah, I was also surprised, because in the case of the walking and balancing algorithm (foot trajectory) in the qual round they were very clear that they don't want us to rewrite low level stuff. We will still write our own code for sure, but would be good if we knew where the hand is going when we use the hand trajectory.
Unless they kinda don't want us to use the hand trajectory for grabbing, who knows.

Anyway, thanks for the answers and best of luck to everyone! :)
content.html:
Yeah, I was also surprised, because in the case of the walking and balancing algorithm (foot trajectory) in the qual round they were very clear that they don't want us to rewrite low level stuff. We will still write our own code for sure, but would be good if we knew where the hand is going when we use the hand trajectory. Unless they kinda don't want us to use the hand trajectory for grabbing, who knows.

Anyway, thanks for the answers and best of luck to everyone! :)

content.html: @Tom_Xiong, @pista999 , @dan77062 , @joeygannon , @knitfoo : is this still an issue since the grasping controller has been released?

content.html: @chapulina Yes, it is. I still can't see the hand frames that @scpeters said should be visible now.
